messages.messageBody:

Your not missing anything, I am. I believe you, of

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nerikawa Nagamaki Tsuba FYI
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, They don t look very difficult to make, so maybe many different craftsmen made them. But my suspicion is that craftsmen that specialized in lacquer work
messages.messageBody:
Jim,

They don't look very difficult to make, so maybe many different craftsmen made them. But my suspicion is that craftsmen that specialized in lacquer work would be the ones to capitalize in the production of these items. I don't know anything about the leather trade in Japan, but this work is still done today on kendo equipment. On a better quality Do (mid-body armor) it is made with bamboo strips and a thick peace of leather that is glued to the strips and then the leather is lacquered over. The lacquered surface is extremely durable.

Moses
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, June 03, 2003 2:58 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nerikawa Nagamaki Tsuba FYI


Mo,
I've wondered just who made these leather fittings. Were they made by general leather workers that made all sorts of items, or by people who specialized in arms and armor? My guess is that they weren't made by the same people who were making metal sword fittings, armor, etc., given the class issues around hide working. Has anyone researched the pre-industrial leather trade in Japan?

Jim



Jim & all,

I see, perhaps it was just a common technique use on different items. Swords, Nagamaki, boken and shinai.

Moses

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nerikawa Nagamaki Tsuba FYI
messages.msgSnippet: Curran, I ve never seen a leather Hoju tsuba, but the metal ones do have a teardrop shaped ana.  Since this example was mounted on a nagamaki pole, the shape
messages.messageBody:
Curran,
I've never seen a leather Hoju tsuba, but the metal ones do have a teardrop
shaped ana. Since this example was mounted on a nagamaki pole, the shape of
the ana matches the shape of the pole. Probably about the same shape as a
shinai. I'm certainly not saying that this tsuba is anywhere near as old as
Kofun jidai. It's probably late Edo period, maybe mid Edo at the oldest.

BTW, the Heian through Muromachi period nerikawa tachi tsuba have the
typical wedge shaped nakago ana that you'd expect for a sword.

Jim

> Tom, Jim, etc.
>
> I refrained on this one, because I figured I didn't
> know enough. Glad to hear Tom speak up.
>
> I've seen only a few examples of the early tsuba shape
> I thought Jim was referring to..., but this one looked
> like an old kendo shinae tsuba to me too. Similar to
> ones an old teacher had on tsuba and shinae preserved
> in the 'school museum' back when I was in highschool
> south of Nagoya in 1989.
> Didn't the old tsuba soft metal, leather and such,
> have more of a teardrop shape to their appeture?-not
> the fattened out oval shape of leather shinae tsuba's
> opening?
>
> Curran
>

----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, June 03, 2003 1:56 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nerikawa Nagamaki Tsuba FYI


Tom & all,
I haven't seen the koshirae for years, but based on Keith's description and what I remember, this guard is mounted on the pole (not the nakago) and would have served as a hand stop rather than a blade stop. The iron parrying bars would have taken care of other blades. I don't recall anything about the leather plate that would suggest that it wasn't contemporary with the rest of the mounting, but my memory of it isn't good enough to base an argument on. There is a somewhat similar koshirae at the bottom of page 82 of Bottomley and Hopson's "Arms and Armor of the Samurai." Scanned here for your convenience:
http://tinyurl.com/dd82

I suppose it's possible that someone transplanted a shinai tsuba onto the nagamaki koshirae. But on the other hand if you set out to make a round leather guard to go on a round wooden stick, I'm not sure how one for a nagamaki pole would or should look different from one for a shinai. Any ideas?

If we were talking about a loose guard not associated with a koshirae, I'd agree with Mo that it's much more likely to have been from a shinai or bokken than a nagamaki. But this one did come on a nagamaki and we have other examples of pole arms mounted like this with a hand guard on the pole and parrying bars either mounted on the nakago or on the pole. Am I missing something?
Jim

--


<http://tinyurl.com/d2ee>http://tinyurl.com/d2ee

Jim-
I just got around to looking at this. Check the size of that
hole dude!Ý Are you sure this is original to the pole? This looks
like a kendo shinai tsuba, a very old one but I would bet it is for a
shinai none the less.
Tom

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nerikawa Nagamaki Tsuba FYI
messages.msgSnippet: Richard, The Hoju tsuba from the Kofun jidai have a large opening for sort of the same reason.  They were mounted on a fitting on the handle rather than on the
messages.messageBody:
Richard,
The Hoju tsuba from the Kofun jidai have a large opening for sort of the same reason. They were mounted on a fitting on the handle rather than on the nakago. So, large ovoid opening rather than a small wedge shaped one. It seems that tsuba started to be mounted on the nakago in the early Heian period.

BTW, there are a couple of surviving kenukigata tachi where the tsuba had to be mounted by sliding it on over the kissaki and down the blade. The tsuba was retained in place with a small pin through the blade. That method didn't seem to last too long.

Jim



Tom et all, there is a pic of a tsuba early on in Hakasui's Nippon-to (
don't have the book in front of me ) that is an old rusted job found in
a tomb from memory, it too has a large opening not unlike the one Jim
posted in his album. ( I hope the grey matter is working correctly )

Tom, that link didn't work for some reason, if others haven't seen this
tsuba look into Jims pics, the filder is called nagamaki tsuba.

Rich


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

south of Nagoya in 1989.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nerikawa Nagamaki Tsuba FYI
messages.msgSnippet: Milt- Kendo per se is a Meiji era development, but Kenjutsu practice with padded armour and bamboo shinae is much older. The fukuro-shinae, a single piece of
messages.messageBody:
Milt-
Kendo per se is a Meiji era development, but Kenjutsu
practice with padded armour and bamboo shinae is much older. The
fukuro-shinae, a single piece of split bamboo covered with leather,
was in use by the Yagyu school and others in the early Edo period.
Remember the discussions on Kanbun Shinto? I for one believe that
approximating the wildly popular shinae was the reason behind the
adoption of that particular sugata...
-t

PS Edo period "Kendo" tsuba were leather, in fact the best
shinae-tsuba to this day are still leather...

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nerikawa Nagamaki Tsuba FYI
messages.msgSnippet: -t und Mo und all, First we have to ask ourselves this question..................... when did kendo come into being  ? The  fencing/swordmanship  schools of
messages.messageBody:
-t und Mo und all,
First we have to ask ourselves this question..................... when did
kendo come into being ? The " fencing/swordmanship " schools of Edo days used
boken, ja ? When I was training in kenjutsu many years ago ( I have since
ceased doing that due to my weakening back ), we used bokken with no plastico
tsuba.

Milt

messages.msgSnippet: Tom, For some reason I really do agree with you (old shinai or boken).  Any way it can be a possibility.  I am not that knowledgeable on tsuba but I have come
messages.messageBody:
Tom,

For some reason I really do agree with you (old shinai or boken). Any way it can be a possibility. I am not that knowledgeable on tsuba but I have come across old tsuba that were on Boken that were lacquered and looked very similar to this one in Japan. Perhaps it was modified? What do you think Jim?

Regards,
Moses

messages.msgSnippet: ... Keith?  If you can take the photo I ll post it.  It s a pretty interesting piece of hardward as I recall. Craig, Thanks.  I do remember that tsuba now that
messages.messageBody:
>Is there any chance of getting a
>picture of the "four pointed iron guard device?"

Keith? If you can take the photo I'll post it. It's a pretty interesting piece of hardward as I recall.

Craig,
Thanks. I do remember that tsuba now that I see it. The seppa dai and nakago ana are unmistakable. I wonder what that sukashi work was all about. It certainly is, um, uninhibited. Interesting example.
Jim

>Since we're talking polearm koshirae, I put up a photo of a nagamaki tsuba
that, foolishly, I no longer own. I recall it being 3"+, very smooth

years ago when we did the Met, perhaps you have more to say about it.

Craig Harris

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nerikawa Nagamaki Tsuba FYI
messages.msgSnippet: John and Rich, Yeah it looks to me like the fabric is similar to what s seen under lacquer on wood.  I don t know much about lacquer (where s John Badenhop?),
messages.messageBody:
John and Rich,
Yeah it looks to me like the fabric is similar to what's seen under lacquer on wood. I don't know much about lacquer (where's John Badenhop?), but I'd guess that it helps the adhesion of the lacquer and/or strengthens the whole structure.

I think that this is the only two layer kawa guard I've seen, too. I've seen up to six layers used. The Edo period ones tend to use fewer layers than the old ones, but I have seen 3 layers used in Kamakura period kawa tsuba.

I put up a detail lifted from the kawatsutsumi tachi koshirae on page 25 of Kajihara-san's Visual Glossary:
http://tinyurl.com/d2q4

Those of you with the book will probably have better luck looking at that. The kawa tsuba has delaminated like those at Oyamazumi, but the upper half is still wrapped in what looks like a cloth bag. I'm not sure if there are any traces of lacquer remaining. There are o-seppa. I have no idea if the lacquer has come off, or if some of these plain kawa tachi tsuba were never lacquered.

Jim




Jim,

Cool! I assume the fabric was that stuff they sometimes use when they
lacquer things? (I had a naginata pole with what appeared
to be fabric under the lacquer once...)

rkg
(Richard George)


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nerikawa Nagamaki Tsuba FYI
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, Thanks for posting this, very interesting. Is there any chance of getting a picture of the four pointed iron guard device? Since we re talking polearm
messages.messageBody:
Jim,

Thanks for posting this, very interesting. Is there any chance of getting a
picture of the "four pointed iron guard device?"

Since we're talking polearm koshirae, I put up a photo of a nagamaki tsuba
that, foolishly, I no longer own. I recall it being 3"+, very smooth
textured iron, thin but strong feeling. Jim, you saw this one a couple of
years ago when we did the Met, perhaps you have more to say about it.

Craig Harris

about. It is 3.5 inches in diameter and .25 inches thick. It is made from
two pieces of leather and it appears that there may be a fabric covering
under the lacquer..you can see a weave looking design on the edges where the
lacquer is cracked away. This particular tsuba fit on the pole about a foot
behind the blade. There is a four pointed iron guard device that goes in
front of it. I don't have the whole pole, but I do have all the forward
parts."
>
> Jim
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Nerikawa Nagamaki Tsuba FYI
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim; This is very interesting.  I had always thought that these were made of at least 3 to 5 layers of sandwiched leather. Interesting to see 2 layers. John
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim;

This is very interesting. I had always thought that these were made of at least 3 to 5 layers of sandwiched leather.

Interesting to see 2 layers.

John
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, May 30, 2003 10:38 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Nerikawa Nagamaki Tsuba FYI


A friend of mine just sent some photos of a leather nagamaki tsuba from his collection. I put them up at:

http://tinyurl.com/d2ee

His description:

"Attached are the pix of that leather nagamaki tsuba I was telling you about. It is 3.5 inches in diameter and .25 inches thick. It is made from two pieces of leather and it appears that there may be a fabric covering under the lacquer..you can see a weave looking design on the edges where the lacquer is cracked away. This particular tsuba fit on the pole about a foot behind the blade. There is a four pointed iron guard device that goes in front of it. I don't have the whole pole, but I do have all the forward parts."

Jim
